cnd14:2.1: "Those who have meditation, those who are free from the dust, and those who sit
cnd14:2.2: down": The Blessed One is a person who has meditation. He who has meditation in
cnd14:2.3: the first jhāna is one who has meditation; ...second jhāna...; ...third
cnd14:2.5: ...no-will meditation...; ...walking meditation with pleasure...; meditation in
cnd14:2.6: emptiness; meditation in non-phase; meditation with unwillingness; in the world
cnd14:2.7: of jhāna, he is also a meditator, a meditation-loving person, a practitioner of
cnd14:2.8: a single state, and a person who values his own interests. "A person who is free
cnd14:2.9: from dust," greed is dust, hatred ..., ignorance ..., anger ..., resentment...
cnd14:2.10: (omitted); all unwholesome deeds are dust. For the Buddha and the Blessed One,
cnd14:2.11: this dust has been cut off, and the roots have been cut off, just like a palm
cnd14:2.12: tree without roots, becoming non-existent for the future. Among living things,
cnd14:2.13: therefore, the Buddha is the one who has no dust, the one who is free from the
cnd14:2.14: dust, the one who has thrown away the dust, the one who has abandoned the dust,
cnd14:2.15: the one who has left the bonds of the dust (, the one who does not correspond to
cnd14:2.16: the dust), and the one who has overcome all the dust.
cnd14:3.1: Greed instead of dust is called grime, "dust" is synonymous with greed, the
cnd14:3.2: person abandons dust in their eyes, so the winner is called the person who has
cnd14:3.3: left the dust. Anger instead of dust is called grime.... Ignorance instead of
cnd14:4.1: "Those who sit down," The Blessed One is sitting in the Rock Temple in Magadha.
cnd14:5.1: "When Muni was sitting on the hillside,
cnd14:5.2: He who had reached the other side of suffering,
cnd14:5.3: The disciples served, with the three knowledges,
cnd14:6.1: Or, in the state where all efforts have ceased, the Blessed One is the one who
cnd14:6.2: sits, the one who has descended, and the one who has practiced... (omitted)
cnd14:7.1: "[Like this Venerable Udaya]": "Like this," the continuation of the sentences,
cnd14:7.2: the connection of the words, the completion of the sentences, the combination of
cnd14:7.3: words, this is the order of the sentence, which is "like this." "Venerable,"
cnd14:7.4: this is a synonym of love, respect, and obedience. "Udaya," the name, title,
cnd14:7.5: security of the Brāhmaṇa, title, word, phrase.
cnd14:8.1: "The one who has completed the duty and the one who has no troubles": For the
cnd14:8.2: Buddha and the Blessed One, all the obligations, what should be done and what
cnd14:8.3: should not be done have been cut off, and the roots have been cut off, just like
cnd14:8.4: a palm tree without roots, gone to non-existence, something that will not be
cnd14:8.5: born in the future. Therefore, the Buddha is the one who has completed the duty.
cnd14:9.2: For the bhikkhus who have cut off the stream,
cnd14:9.3: For those who have cut off what should be done and what should not be done,
cnd14:9.4: The scorching heat is not found."
cnd14:10.1: "Should be the doer, the one who has no troubles": There are four types of
cnd14:10.2: troubles: the troubles of desire, the troubles of being, the troubles of seeing,
cnd14:10.3: and the troubles of ignorance. Those troubles have been abandoned by the Buddha
cnd14:10.4: and the Blessed One, the root has been cut off, .... Therefore, the Buddha is a
cnd14:11.1: "Reached the other side in all dhammas": The Blessed One is the one who has

cnd14:11.6: four holy paths; ...of the testimony of destruction; the one who waits until he

cnd14:11.8: holy precepts, the highest (pāramitā) reacher; the free reacher and the highest
cnd14:11.9: reacher in the holy sanctuary; the free reacher in the holy wisdom, the highest,
cnd14:11.10: the one who has reached the end; the one who is free and the highest in the
cnd14:11.11: sacred liberation, the one who has reached the other side, the one who has
cnd14:11.12: reached the ultimate (target); the one who has reached finality, the one who has
cnd14:11.13: reached the end; has reached the border; ...reached rescue; reached shelter;

cnd14:12.1: "The needy come with questions": I come with questions as needed, I come if I

cnd14:13.1: "Please tell us about the liberation of the complete wisdom": The liberation of
cnd14:13.2: the complete wisdom is called the liberation of the Arahant state. Please tell

cnd14:14.1: "The destruction of ignorance": The destruction of ignorance, breaking,

cnd14:16.1: "Cut off the desire for desire": "Desire," which is the desire of desire, the
cnd14:16.2: greed of desire, the joy..., the thirst..., love, craving, enthusiasm,
cnd14:16.3: fascination, seizure, torrent, harness (binding), attachment, the cover of
cnd14:16.4: desire. "The renunciation of the desire for desire": the renunciation, calmness,

cnd14:18.1: "Both with regard to sorrows": "Sorrows" are undesirable sufferings of the

cnd14:18.3: the heart contact. "Both with regards to sorrow": The desire and sorrow, the
cnd14:18.4: cessation, calm, stopping, non-living, and Nibbāna.

cnd14:20.1: "Prevention of regret": "Regret," the inaction of the hands (evil uneasiness) is
cnd14:20.2: regret, the inaction of the feet is also regret, the inaction of the hands and
cnd14:20.3: feet is also regret, the inappropriate is considered as appropriate, appropriate
cnd14:20.4: is thought to be inappropriate, the timely is thought to be untimely, the
cnd14:20.5: innocent is thought to be sinful, the sinful is thought to be innocent, regret
cnd14:20.6: is like this; the path to regret, the state of regret, the remorse of the heart,
cnd14:20.7: the confusion of the mind, this is called regret. In addition, regret, heart
cnd14:20.8: remorse, and confusion of mind arise from two factors: what is done and what is
cnd14:20.9: not done. How do things that have been done and things that have not been done
cnd14:20.10: cause regret, heart remorse, and confusion of mind? "I did the evil deeds of the
cnd14:20.11: body, but the good deeds of the body were not done by me." He had regrets,
cnd14:20.12: remorse in his heart, and confusion of mind; "I did the evil deeds of speech,
cnd14:20.13: ...(omitted)." "I did the evil deeds of action...." "I did the killing, and the
cnd14:20.14: abstinence from killing was not done by me.".... "Taking what wasn't given...,
cnd14:20.15: not giving...; adultery..., abstention from adultery....; lying..., divisive
cnd14:20.16: speech..., vicious language..., slurs..., greed..., malice..., wrong views...."
cnd14:20.17: He had regrets, heart remorse, and confusion of intentions. Regret, heart
cnd14:20.18: remorse, and confusion arise with what has been done and has not been done.

cnd14:25.4: first, and it is the forerunner of complete intellectual liberation. Or,

cnd14:33.1: "Joy is the knot of the world": Joy is called thirst, that is greed.... This is
cnd14:33.2: called joy. All happiness is the knot, adhesion, bondage, and defilement of the
cnd14:33.3: world, and is the harness, ...of the world.
cnd14:34.1: "Reflection is its wandering": "Reflection," there are nine types of thinking:
cnd14:34.2: about pleasure, maliciously, of harm, of relatives, of land, of immortality, of
cnd14:34.3: sympathy with others, and of respect and reputation, and the thought related to
cnd14:34.4: not being scorned are called the nine types of thinking. These nine types of
cnd14:34.5: thinking are the wandering and roaming of the world.
cnd14:35.1: "With the surrender of thirst, it is called Nibbāna like this": "Thirst for

cnd14:35.3: surrender of thirst, it is called Nibbāna like this": With the surrender of
cnd14:35.4: thirst, calming, stopping, and cessation; it is called, said, told, talked,
cnd14:35.5: explained to be said as Nibbāna.

cnd14:41.1: <em>80 : (The Blessed One:) For those who are not happy in feeling
cnd14:41.5: <em>80 : (The Blessed One:) For those who are not happy in feeling

cnd14:42.1: "One who is not happy in feeling within and outside of oneself": The feeling
cnd14:42.2: within oneself is subject to perception and the one who inhabits it is not
cnd14:42.3: happy, unwelcome, does not hold, persevere, cling; he abandons, drives away,
cnd14:42.4: makes to end, makes it to go to non-existence; the feeling outside of
cnd14:42.5: oneself...; the feeling within and outside of the self...; the feeling in
cnd14:42.6: oneself is an aggregation of dhammas, and the one who lives according to that
cnd14:42.7: observation...; the feeling in oneself is the dhamma of dissipation, and the one
cnd14:42.8: who lives according to that observation...; the feeling outside of oneself is an
cnd14:42.9: aggregation... ...dissipation...; ...inside and outside of oneself...; the one
cnd14:42.10: who lives according to these twelve forms of experience is not happy, does not
cnd14:42.11: welcome, does not hold, persevere, cling; he abandons, drives away, makes it to
cnd14:42.12: end, makes it go to non-existence.
cnd14:43.1: Or, the one who regards experience as impermanence is not happy, unwelcome, and
cnd14:43.2: does not insist on feeling, rejoicing, ....; suffering, sick, tumor, arrow,
cnd14:43.3: ...makes it go to non-existence; in these forty-two forms of feeling, the one
cnd14:43.4: who is not happy, welcome, ...makes it go to non-existence.
cnd14:44.1: "This is the case for the mindful walker": This is the way for the mindful and
cnd14:44.2: righteous walker, dweller, actor, on-goer, guarder, and survivor.
cnd14:45.1: "Consciousness is stopped": Consciousness that does blessing, non-blessing,
cnd14:45.2: consciousness that does not move [SN.12.51] is destroyed, calmed down, walked to
